History of AI and Social Media

Early AI in social media began with basic automation tools like chatbots and recommendation engines, which used rule-based systems to simulate human interaction and personalize content. Over time, these evolved into generative AI models capable of creating text, images, and videos, transforming how platforms engage users and manage content.

In 2017, only 6% of U.S. companies used AI, with adoption concentrated in large firms and tech-centric industries like social media. By 2023, AI use had expanded significantly, driven by process innovation, younger leadership, and venture-backed startups, enabling platforms to automate moderation, optimize engagement, and scale personalization.

Today, AI in social media is dominated by multimodal foundation models and generative AI, which power automated content creation, feed curation, and real-time moderation. Industry leads in deploying these models, with social media platforms using them to enhance user experience and manage vast volumes of data and interactions.
